messages.about.page.sub.header.1.text.1.defaultMe: On January 27, 2021, President Biden directed the Council on Environmental Quality (CEQ) to create a climate and economic justice screening tool. The purpose of the tool is to help Federal agencies identify disadvantaged communities and provide socioeconomic, environmental, and climate information and data to inform decisions that may affect these communities. The tool identifies disadvantaged communities as communities of focus through publicly available, nationally consistent, high-quality data.
messages.about.page.sub.header.1.text.2.defaultMe: The current version of the tool is in a public beta form and will be updated based on feedback from the public.
messages.about.page.sub.header.2.text.1.defaultMe: The tool will provide important information for the Justice40 Initiative. The goal of the Justice40 Initiative is to provide 40-percent of the overall benefits of certain federal programs in seven key areas to disadvantaged communities. These seven key areas are: climate change, clean energy and energy efficiency, clean transit, affordable and sustainable housing, training and workforce development, the remediation and reduction of legacy pollution, and the development of critical clean water infrastructure.
messages.about.page.sub.header.2.text.2.defaultMe: Read more about the Justice40 Initiative in President Biden’s

messages.datasetContainer.info.defaultMessage: The datasets come from a variety of sources and were selected based on relevance, availability, recency, and quality. The datasets seek to identify a range of human health, environmental, climate-related, and other cumulative impacts on communities.

messages.mapIntro.censusBlockGroupDefinition.defa: A census block group is generally between 600 and 3,000 people. It is the smallest geographical unit for which the U.S. Census Bureau publishes sample data.
messages.mapIntro.censusBlockGroupDefinition.desc: cites the definition and helpful information about census groups

messages.methodology.page.paragraph.first.default: The methodology for identifying communities of focus is currently in a draft, pre-decisional form that may change over time as more datasets become available.
messages.methodology.step.1.a.info.1.defaultMessa: If a census block group is in a metropolitan area, this value is the median income of the census block group calculated as a percent of the metropolitan area’s median income.
messages.methodology.step.1.a.info.2.defaultMessa: If a census block group is not in a metropolitan area, this value is the median income of the census block group calculated as a percent of the state’s median income.
messages.methodology.step.1.b.heading.defaultMess: Percent of households below or at 100% of the federal poverty line
messages.methodology.step.1.c.heading.defaultMess: The high school degree achievement rate for adults 25 years and older
messages.methodology.step.1.c.info.defaultMessage: The percent of individuals who are 25 or older who have received a high school degree.
messages.methodology.step.1.info.defaultMessage: The methodology includes the following inputs that are equally weighted.
messages.methodology.step.2.info.defaultMessage: Under the existing formula, a census block group will be considered a community of focus if:
messages.methodology.steps.2.b.info.defaultMessag: This is the percent of households in a state with a household income below or at 100% of the {federalPovertyLine}. This federal poverty line is calculated based on the composition of each household (e.g., based on household size), but it does not vary geographically.
messages.methodology.steps.2.b.info.description: Download the draft list of communities of focus and datasets used.
messages.methodology.steps.2.formula.description: Formala used to calculate communities of focus
messages.methodology.steps.description.1.defaultM: The methodology for identifying communities of focus is calculated at the census block group level. Census block geographical boundaries are determined by the U.S. Census Bureau once every ten years. This tool utilizes the census block boundaries from 2010.
messages.methodology.steps.description.2.defaultM: The following describes the process for identifying communities of focus.
